“It was always so heartbreaking when the Dream Act fell short. I would take it personally. All those extra visits to professors and the late-night study groups? It wasn’t enough. All the work to help my school or my community? It felt like it didn’t matter. Each time the bill went down was like a punch in the gut. I didn’t feel like I mattered; I felt like an alien. You cry yourself to sleep over the stress. Year after year. The anxiety. The unknown. DACA was the only small window of hope I had.

In multiple decisions this week, the Supreme Court has reminded me of something I’d forgotten: this country is built on love. For so long, I was a bird in a cage. Now, I can breathe easier: I will not return to confinement. My dreams will not be deferred.”

Victoria Botello
Former Big KIPPster

This has been a difficult few weeks followed by a tough weekend leaving us angry, sad, and in mourning of the murder of Houstonian, George Floyd and so many others who have lost their lives; we are all witnessing the racial injustice that has been plaguing our country throughout our history. We are tired of the senseless killing of Black men and women; we need a more compassionate, just world. Our actions matter and our voices need to be heard.

Many of us want to take action. There are peaceful protests taking place in all of four of the cities where our communities are, and we encourage our Team & Family to safely participate in these peaceful protests to call attention to the senseless murders and injustices that Black men and women are facing.

This has been a difficult few weeks followed by a tough weekend leaving us angry, sad, and in mourning of the murder of Houstonian, George Floyd and so many others who have lost their lives; we are all witnessing the racial injustice that has been plaguing our country throughout our history. We are tired of the senseless killing of Black men and women; we need a more compassionate, just world. Our actions matter and our voices need to be heard.

Many of us want to take action. There are peaceful protests taking place in all of four of the cities where our communities are, and we encourage our Team & Family to safely participate in these peaceful protests to call attention to the senseless murders and injustices that Black men and women are facing.

We know there is more that needs to be done and more that we will do in a thoughtful and intentional way.

Yesterday, we shared the news that distance learning and Grab & Go meal service would continue through the end of the school year, but we would not return to our school buildings before the end of the year. For a lot of us, our schools serve as a haven where we enjoy friendships, grow our brains, and build memories that we carry with us.

Although we are heartbroken about the news, we are also thankful.

Thankful for our students that continue to work hard during an unprecedented time, our teachers for bringing academic rigor and joy to our virtual classrooms, our parents for adding teacher to an already long list of duties, our child nutrition services department and operations team for quickly pivoting to serve Grab & Go meals to ALL children in our community, and all of our Team & Family members working behind the scenes in service to our KIPPsters and their families.

In a difficult time, we have gratitude and pride seeing all that we can accomplish when we work together.

Share with us in the comments below who/what you are thankful for during this season? #ThankfulThursday

The health and safety of our KIPP Texas Public Schools students and staff is our priority. We have been in consultation with local and state leaders and health officials concerning COVID-19 and the effects on the communities where we educate students.

As a result, we have made the difficult decision that we will NOT return to our school buildings for the remainder of this school year.

Instead, we will continue distance learning with our KIPPsters and work remotely through the school calendar year. Likewise, we will continue to provide meal service to our families and communities. This decision affects all 55 KIPP Texas Public Schools in Austin, Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston, and San Antonio.

Did you know that at the 1968 Olympic Games, olympians Tommie Smith and John Carlos, winners of the gold and bronze medals, respectively, in the event, had come to the ceremony dressed to protest: wearing black socks and no shoes to symbolize African-American poverty, a black glove to express African-American strength and unity. (Smith also wore a scarf, and Carlos beads, in memory of lynching victims.)

As the national anthem played and an international TV audience watched, each man bowed his head and raised a fist. After the two were banished, images of their gesture entered the iconography of athletic protest.

"I went up there as a dignified black man and said: ‘What's going on is wrong,' " Carlos says. Their protest, Smith says, "was a cry for freedom and for human rights. We had to be seen because we couldn't be heard."

A display honoring this moment was displayed at KIPP Courage Prep's Honoring Black History event.

Did you know? Otis Boykin was an African-American Inventor and Engineer, best known for his work in the field of Electronics and his involvement in the improvement of the Pacemaker.

Otis Boykin’s most notable contribution to science was likely the circuit improvements he made to pacemakers after losing his mother to heart failure — a contribution that has saved countless lives since. But this single improvement was among a long list of achievements.

Boykin had 26 patents in his name and is famed for the development of IBM computers, burglar-proof cash register, chemical air filters, and an electronic resistor used in controlled missiles and other devices.

Applications are required for all potential students not currently enrolled in a KIPP Texas school.

Applications must be received by February 21, 2020, to be included in the lottery. Applications received after February 21, 2020, will be placed on the waiting list in the order in which they are received.

The lottery for the 2020-21 school year will take place on March 2, 2020. On this day, names are drawn through a random, automated lottery process, and families are notified of their admission status soon afterward. If there are not enough open seats available, children will be placed on a waitlist. If and when seats become available at each KIPP school, we will notify families in the order of the waitlist.

Additionally, families can log into their SchoolMint account to see the status of their child’s enrollment at any time.

Apply today at kipptexas.org/enroll

Today is World Suicide Prevention Day.

As a KIPP Texas family, we must take care of one another by being kind and loving. We all go through experiences that might make us feel alone, worthless, or unseen. We believe that the best approach to getting help is by talking to someone about it. That someone could be a teacher, a School Leader, a classmate, a parent, and any other individual you trust.

If you or someone you know needs help immediately, call the Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255.

Energetic members of the San Antonio staff powerfully greeted our school leaders and teachers to kick off the start of the day with excitement, positivity, and happiness!

Today we celebrate #Juneteenth, a commemorative holiday that honors the freedom and heritage of African-American slaves. On June 19, 1865, the abolition of slavery was announced in the state of Texas.

As we honor the importance of this day, let us continue to work together to create a more equitable society for all marginalized groups.
